title: Skill Exchange Platform — Initial Build

requirements.text: Implement a user registration and profile management system. Users must be able to create a profile with their name, bio, skills they can teach (offered skills), and skills they want to learn (wanted skills). Profiles must be stored on-chain and retrievable by user principal.

quotes: enables users to exchange skills with one another
The platform allows users to teach skills they already possess and learn new skills from others

acceptanceCriteria: A user can register and create a profile with name, bio, offered skills, and wanted skills.
A user can view and edit their own profile.
Profile data is persisted on the backend and retrievable by principal ID.
The profile page displays offered and wanted skills as distinct lists.

requirements.text: Implement a skill listing and browsing/search system. Users must be able to browse all registered users and their offered skills, and search/filter by skill name or category.

quotes: people with useful skills have no proper way to share their knowledge

acceptanceCriteria: A browsable directory of users and their offered skills is displayed on a dedicated page.
Users can search by skill name and see matching results in real time.
Each listing shows the user's name, offered skills, and a link to their profile.
The backend exposes a query to return all users or filter by skill keyword.

requirements.text: Implement a skill exchange matching system. When a user views another user's profile and their offered/wanted skills are complementary (user A wants what user B offers, and vice versa), highlight the match and allow user A to send an exchange request to user B.

quotes: connect users with complementary skills and enable secure, peer-to-peer skill exchange

acceptanceCriteria: The system detects when two users have complementary skills and surfaces a 'Match' indicator on their profiles.
A logged-in user can send an exchange request to another user.
The recipient can accept or decline the exchange request.
Accepted matches appear in both users' dashboards under 'Active Exchanges'.
Exchange request state (pending, accepted, declined) is persisted on the backend.

requirements.text: Implement a secure in-platform messaging system between matched users. Only users with an accepted exchange match may exchange messages. Messages are stored on the backend and displayed in a conversation thread UI.
acceptanceCriteria: Only users with an accepted exchange can initiate or view a conversation.
Messages are sent, stored, and retrieved from the backend.
A conversation thread UI shows messages ordered chronologically.
New messages from the other party are visible upon page refresh.

requirements.text: Implement a ratings and reviews system for completed skill exchange sessions. After an exchange, each participant can leave a numeric rating (1–5 stars) and a short text review for the other user. Aggregate ratings are displayed on user profiles.
acceptanceCriteria: A user can submit a rating (1–5 stars) and an optional text review for their exchange partner after an accepted exchange.
Each user's profile displays their average rating and all reviews they have received.
A user cannot rate the same exchange more than once.
Ratings and reviews are persisted on the backend.

requirements.text: Apply a cohesive, modern visual theme across the entire application. Use a warm, earthy color palette (e.g., terracotta, sage green, off-white) with clean sans-serif typography, generous whitespace, card-based layouts for skill listings and profiles, and subtle accent highlights for match/action states. The aesthetic should feel approachable, community-driven, and distinct from typical edtech platforms.
acceptanceCriteria: The color palette and typography are consistent across all pages.
Skill cards, profile cards, and exchange request UI all use the same design language.
The theme is visibly distinct from default browser or bootstrap styles.
Matched skill indicators use a clearly distinguishable accent color.

constraints: All backend logic must reside in a single Motoko actor in backend/main.mo.
Authentication must use Internet Identity only; no third-party auth providers.
Do not use any external databases; all state must be stored in Motoko stable variables.
Messaging is only available between users with an accepted exchange match — not open to all users.
Do not implement real-time WebSocket-based messaging; polling on page load/refresh is acceptable.
nonGoals: No paid content, course fees, or payment processing.
No video conferencing or live session scheduling.
No mobile app or React Native build.
No external AI-based skill matching or recommendations.
No admin dashboard or moderation tools in this initial build.
